Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: Your I04iend calls you in the middle of the night, crying, because they just received some devastating family news.
Expectation2: Assemble and construct wooden frameworks, furniture, or cabinetry
Situation2: The carpenter is building custom cabinetry and needs to collaborate with other construction professionals to complete the project on time
Story: My phone buzzed at 2 a.m., jolting me awake. It was Sam, my oldest friend, sobbing so hard I could barely make out the words. He’d just lost his father. I sat up, heart pounding, trying to listen, to be the friend he needed—someone who would stay on the line, offer comfort, and just be there. But as I murmured words of support, my mind kept drifting to the job site. The cabinetry project was behind schedule, and the electricians and plumbers were coming at dawn. If I didn’t get the framework ready, the whole team would be delayed, and I’d let everyone down. I could hear the expectation in Sam’s voice, desperate for me to stay, and I could feel the weight of my responsibility as a carpenter pressing on my chest. I wanted to be the friend who never left, but I also needed to be the professional who kept his word. My hands trembled as I tried to balance the phone and my thoughts, torn between two worlds that suddenly felt impossibly far apart.
